boat.full_description:
Named 'Trix' until 1946 when she was re-named 'Thistle', 'Lady Trix' is a one off lightweight racing yacht designed by Alfred Mylne and built on the Clyde, Scotland in 1909. She often raced in the 1950s with the 6 metre class. She was taken to France in the 1990s. In 2006, she was entrusted to Bruno Barbara (Candela) for restoration and renamed again, 'Lady Trix'.

In August 2008, at Noirmoutier, the 6mJI 'Elfe' holed 'Lady Trix' amidships, causing significant damage.

In 2009, her centenary year, she celebrated in style. Invited by H.S.H Prince Albert, and with Bruno Peyron at the helm, 'Lady Trix' came in second at the Monaco Classic Week and also won the 'Voiles de Saint-Tropez'.

Recollections from David Johnston, June 2018

I sailed on her in the early 1970s along with my father, Bill Johnston, who is now aged 87.  My father was a member of her regular racing crew from about 1971 to 1975 when 'Thistle' was owned by Dr Andrew Motherwell and raced from Royal Gourock Yacht Club.  

When Andrew emigrated to Australia he sold her to Dr Jimmy Buchanan who kept her at Otter Ferry. A few years later Jimmy sold her to the Coghill family who gave it as a wedding present to their son Frank & Jenny (nee Lee). I sailed on her occasionally with Frank & Jenny. She was based at Cardwell Bay Sailing Club in Gourock at the time.

Coming back to my father’s connection, when he first sailed with his friend Andrew Motherwell, he was surprised and delighted to find he already knew the boat. Dad had in fact sailed on her as a young man in the late 1940s when she was owned by his friend Sandy Denny, whose family owned Denny’s shipyard in Dumbarton.

More recently, 'Thistle' was restored by a French boatyard and raced - by Bruno Peyron, no less - on the Mediterranean classic yacht regatta circuit. She was re-named 'Lady Trix', after her original 1909 name of 'Trix'.  In fact her rudder post, when I sailed on her in the 1970s, still had the name 'Trix' engraved into the brass top fitting. 

It seems she was hit by a 6 metre and holed badly in a regatta at Antibes. There were magazine reports and photographs of the collision, and I have not heard of her since. The magazine articles of the collision, as well as an article describing the lengthy restoration project, may be found on the internet by googling “Lady Trix yacht”.

I believed she was built for Lady Coats (wife of a scion of the Paisley thread-making dynasty), but there is another story that she was built for the wife of a Glasgow steel magnate who was well known to Alfred Mylne, the designer.  

I hope this provides a little more colour about this wonderful boat. She handled beautifully and was a joy to sail. She was the first yacht I sailed on and I have very happy memories of sailing and racing her in my early teens with Andrew and my Dad.

With warm memories, David Johnston

ownerships.text: There are two versions of her first ownership:

ownerships.note: 1. She was ordered for a Miss C Howden’s 18th birthday. This young lady’s father appears to be the owner of Howden Engineering, and known to Alfred Mylne. Howdens was a pioneering firm of industrial engineers which exists to this day.

ownerships.note: 2. The lore around Royal Gourock YC was that she was built for Lady Coats, perhaps biased by the Club’s early connections to the Coats family (known for their thread spinning and cloth weaving businesses). It was one of the (several) Coats baronets who had the Clubhouse built in 1894, and donated to the club membership under a Deed of Trust. A member of the same family, Sir Thomas Glen-Coats, distinguished himself by winning the 12 metre gold at the 1908 Olympics. The same fellow was an apprentice yacht designer and assistant to Alfred Mylne. Although there is a certain roundness to this version, that does not necessarily mean it is true!

boat.short_description: 'Thistle', previously known as 'Trix' until 1946, was built in Scotland, 1909 to an Alfred Mylne design. In 2006, she was renamed again, 'Lady Trix' following a major restoration in France.
